snippet: Perched atop a tall monument, two stern-looking bronze owls whose eyes glow green have long been among New York City’s more obscure architectural oddities.
abstract: Pair of bronze owls with glowing eyes perched atop granite monument in northern part of park in Manhattan's Herald Square are among New York City's more obscure architectural oddities; owl's were commissioned in early 20th century by James Gordon Bennet Jr, son of New York Herald Newspaper publisher James Gordon Bennett, known eccentric and fan of owls.
lead_paragraph: Perched atop a tall monument, two stern-looking bronze owls whose eyes glow green have long been among New York City’s more obscure architectural oddities.

headline.main: With a Bird’s-Eye View of Herald Square, Seeing All but Noticed by Few
headline.print_headline: With a Bird’s-Eye View Of Herald Square, Seeing All And Yet Noticed by Few
